caption:
Il primo principio del #datafeminism secondo @kanarinkaprojects e Lauren F. Klein ha a che fare con il potere. Ci sono ben due capitoli a riguardo e sono quelli che mi hanno aperto gli occhi sul percheÃÅ il femminismo riguarda il potere e il privilegio: lo sapevi che prima della nascita della figlia di Serena Williams nessuno era mai andato in tv a parlare del fatto che le donne nere negli Stati Uniti rischiano di morire di parto 3 volte di piuÃÄ rispetto alle donne bianche? Nessuno aveva mai raccolto questi dati a livello istituzionale. Ecco quindi un primo punto: a volte i dati non ci sono, e bisogna cominciare a raccoglierli per esporre un privilegio o un'ingiustizia. Questi dati cercati e analizzati in modo autonomo da associazioni e attivist3 si chiamano #counterdata. Un esempio? La mappa dei cimiteri dei feti in Italia realizzata da @_jenniferguerra_. O la mappa dei femminicidi in Messico fatta dalla ricercatrice MariÃÄa Salguero, il lavoro della fondazione Data2X per i paesi economicamente svantaggiati. In questo caso parliamo di dati che mancano, di gender data gap, a cui @ccriadoperez ha dedicato un intero libro. Ma andiamo oltre. Usando la matrice del dominio possiamo prendere dati esistenti - ma anche gli algoritmi - e capire quale sistema di potere e dominio portano avanti. Le due autrici raccomandano di chiedersi: chi ha RACCOLTO questi dati (e chi eÃÄ rimasto fuori dal processo di raccolta), chi ne avraÃÄ BENEFICIO, quali sono le PRIORITAÃÄ osservate per l'uso di questi dati? Nel corso degli anni la data science ha escluso persone che non fossero bianche e di sesso maschile, questo ha prodotto una tecnologia che rispecchia una visione privilegiata. I software di riconoscimento facciale non riconoscevano i volti non neri fino al lavoro magistrale di @oyfulcode sul tema. Bisogna ricostituire una DATA JUSTICE, per ritrovare l'equitaÃÄ e sfidare l'oppressione sistemica.

[Questo post eÃÄ una sintesi in italiano con intento divulgativo dei primi due capitoli del libro Data Feminism, edito da @mitpress, che si trova online gratuitamente - googlando. Alla prossima puntata!]

#datajustice #dataequity #matrixdomination #tispiegoildatafeminism #tispiegoildato

caption:
PercheÃÅ femminismo dei dati? C‚ÄôeÃÄ bisogno di aggiungere l‚Äôaggettivo femminista a tutto quello che facciamo? Il libro di @kanarinkaprojects e Lauren F. Klein credo sia stato per me lo spartiacque tra il comprendere veramente cosa sia l‚Äôapproccio femminista intersezionale e l‚Äôidea che sia ‚Äúun movimento per i diritti delle donne‚Äù. Ecco, non proprio. Il #datafeminism ha a che fare con l‚Äôaccesso al potere, con il (riconoscimento del) privilegio, con la lotta per l‚ÄôequitaÃÄ e con le domande, le mille domande, che dobbiamo farci quando usiamo i dati o la tecnologia per affrontare questi problemi. Vi parlo da mesi di questo lavoro e finalmente ho deciso che approfondiremo 1 o 2 volte a settimana (gli imprevisti sono sempre in agguato, accettiamolo) uno per uno i principi del #datafeminism che sono anche i titoli dei capitoli. 

Il libro eÃÄ disponibile gratuitamente online su @mitpress (googlate). Ogni pagina per me eÃÄ stata veramente un aha moment sul femminismo all‚Äôopera in un ambito come quello della data science e dell‚Äôintelligenza artificiale dominato da persone bianche, di sesso maschile, eterosessuali. Magari qualche nerd come me laÃÄ fuori ha bisogno di questa spinta per dichiararsi e agire da femminista, quindi ecco, pront3 via!
.
.
.
#catherinedignazio #laurenklein #femminismointersezionale #tispiegoildatafeminism #tispiegoildato

caption:
‚Å£DATA FEMINISM - I spoke about this recently with @melanie_ewan in our IG Live for @witworld_, but recently I‚Äôve become so consumed by this book. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
The authors Catherine D‚Äôlgnazio and Lauren F. Klein write: ‚ÄúToday, data science is a form of power. It has been used to expose injustice, improve health outcomes and topple governments. But it has also been used to discriminate, police, and surveil. This potential for good, on one hand, and harm, on the other, makes it essential to ask: Data science by whom?‚Äù‚†Ä
‚†Ä
The book goes on to explore how data needs to be redefined and looked at through an intersectional lens. One that centers and is founded on feminist thought. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
These are the seven core principles the authors have developed to guide our understanding of data science:‚†Ä
‚†Ä
1. Examine power.‚†Ä
2. Challenge power. ‚†Ä
3. Elevate emotion and embodiment. ‚†Ä
4. Rethink binaries and hierarchies. ‚†Ä
5. Embrace pluralism. ‚†Ä
6. Consider context. ‚†Ä
7. Make labor visible. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Not coming from a STEM background, I‚Äôm really enjoying diving into this learning and nerding out on all things data science. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
What are you learning about right now?‚†Ä
‚†Ä
 #DataFeminism #WomenInTech #WomenInSTEM #DataScience #WomenInTechWorld #BetterTogether #WomenInTechnology #GenderEquality #GenderEquity #DiversityMatters #SheLovesTech

In this online discussion session, Tracey Bowen throws a much needed spotlight on the disturbing prevalence of bias coded into algorithms. The session will start with a short film screening followed by a Q&A with Tracey, focusing on Racial Justice in Data & AI. We‚Äôll explore where we go from here by introducing new voices to the conversation, dissecting the contributing factors, and asking how we can resist the spread of ‚Äòracist robots‚Äô.

üìÜ 13 October, online. Booking link in bio.

@swctn #digitaltechnology #digitalspace #data #accessibility #AI #racialjustice #algorithms #datafeminism #bias

caption:
Artist and Data researcher, Tracey Bowen, comes from a creative technology background in Music. Recently she has been opening up her practice to address issues of inclusivity and bias in tech. Diversity and equitable solutions are now a central focus of her practice.

üåê Tracey will be holding an online discussion on 13 October, throwing a much needed spotlight on the disturbing prevalence of bias coded into algorithms. Booking link in bio.

caption:
If surveillance during COVID-19 has resulted in fear and violence for marginalised communities, then how do we reconcile it with a state's duty of social welfare? @cpaprojectindia's Nikita Sonavane and Ameya Bokil explore what it means to build a system of trust and care.
.
Please feel free to share/use the images and content, but don't forget to attribute/tag @inetdemocracy. You will have our eternal gratitude.
.
How did the #pandemic unfold for those who exist at the margins of the society? Watch this space for conversations @so_radhikal has had while researching what pandemic surveillance looks like for marginalised communities in India, as designed by @harmeetrahal.
.

caption:
The facial recognition systems being used today are biased and flawed. Coded Bias takes a deep dive into the fears and faults of facial recognition systems while detailing the issues with many aspects of the way we are now tracked in society. See this FREE documentary Tuesday, Sept. 15 at 7:30PM and Sunday, Sept. 20 at 4PM by visiting arts.wcu.edu/codedbias or visiting the link in our bio. Swipe for more watching details.

Once the content becomes available at the start time, you‚Äôll have two hours to start watching the film and then after you start the film, you have another 3 hours to finish it. The film is approximately 90 minutes long. 

The film is followed by an interview with the director and producer, Shalini Kantayya.

caption:
Facial recognition systems do not see dark-skinned faces accurately. Coded Bias follows one woman's journey to push for the first-ever legislation in the U.S. to govern against bias in the algorithms that impact us all.

Watch the documentary for free with Bardo Arts Center! The films are hosted through the platform, Eventive, and can be watched on a browser on a computer or mobile device, or through the Eventive app on Roku, Apple TV, Firestick, and more. Get free tickets at arts.wcu.edu/codedbias or click on the link in our bio.

Once the content becomes available at the start time, you‚Äôll have two hours to start watching the film and then after you start the film, you have another 3 hours to finish it. The film is approximately 90 minutes long.

caption:
What does it mean to be a female collective on the internet in the 21st century? 

We are extremely happy to introduce our new collaboration with Women of 21st Century!! @women21stcentury is a curatorial collective and on-going online research project focusing on post-feminism and intersectional practices between art, science, culture, and technology. 

Since our mode of female collective work is predominately online, we cannot take the internet for granted for while it is a space of great potential, it is also riddled with issues relating to gender inequality, racism, surveillance, and more. Issues that while mostly invisible to our day to day perception continuously shape ouf reality --one that today upholds colonial, patriarchal, and extractivist ideaologies. Because it is nor enough to produce political content online this female collaboration between Collective Rewilding and W21 seeks to problematize the very space and medium of enunciation - technology, the internet, and our digital culture more generally. #datafeminism 

Using data science from a feminist perspective W21 is looking beyond women on the internet and into women changing data on it. W21 quote Catherine D‚ÄôIgnazio and Lauren F. Klein: "The narratives around big data and data science are overwhelmingly white, male, and techno-heroic. Data Feminism offers strategies for data scientists to learn how feminism can help work toward justice. Data Feminism is about much more than gender. It is about power, about who has it and who doesn't, and about how those differentials of power can be challenged and changed." üì∑ @vns_matrix üëÅüëÅ @transmediale Undaddy Mainframe (2014), Direct Line (2015) and VNS Matrix‚Äôs A Cyberfeminist Manifesto for the 21st Century (1991) üíôüíôüíô #cyberfeminism #vnsmatrix #bravenewgirls #collective #W21 #women21stcentury

caption:
One of our favourite books published this year. In it, Catherine D‚ÄôIgnazio and Lauren F. Klein outline 7 principles of Data Feminism:

1. Examine power
2. Challenge power 
3. Elevate emotion and embodiment
4. Rethink binaries and hierarchies 
5. Embrace pluralism 
6. Consider context
7. Make labour visible 

Each chapter pursues these principles in detail, drawing examples from the field of data science. Highly recommend! #datafeminism #datajustice

caption:
As a Muslim woman living in a predominantly Muslim neighbourhood in Jharkhand, Salma*, a nurse, narrates how she had to navigate the constant drone and police surveillance in order to go to work. With no explanations provided for the police crackdown and a complete restriction on mobility, residents lived in constant fear of stepping out of their houses, even if it was just to buy medicines. With drones in the sky and violence outside their homes, for many, everyday life seemed to come to a standstill.

People world over have turned to technology as a solution to their woes, whether professional or personal, during the pandemic. Governments, too, have deployed a version of technology solutionism with the reliance on technology for financial relief schemes. But relief for whom? What happens when individuals get left out of the conversations around social protection? @bds.samabhabona Director Raina Roy explains the dire conditions trans sex workers have found themselves in in the course of the lockdown, with technology providing a solution only to some.
.

caption:
#Repost @inetdemocracy
‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢
Ludhiana, Punjab, India

ASHA workers have been at the forefront of India's healthcare system as community health workers much before the pandemic. But now, they find themselves having to take on work that they have never done before in order to tackle this crisis. Ranjit Kaur, Union Leader (Punjab), All India ASHA Worker and Facilitators Union, explains in detail the kind of problems Punjab's ASHA workers are facing while trying to do their job without proper training or technical know-how during the pandemic. Punjab government's COVID19 tracing app, 'Ghar Ghar Nigrani', has made ASHA workers agents of state surveillance--all while struggling with digital literacy, access to mobile phones and more themselves.
.

caption:
Posted @withregram ‚Ä¢ @inetdemocracy During COVID-19, the state has implemented various social protection schemes to provide financial relief to the most marginalised. Technology, namely direct benefit transfers and the JAM (Jan Dhan-Aadhar-Mobile) trinity, have been central to their efforts. Manju Rajput and Dhrishti Agarwal, who work with the grassroots organisation Aajeevika Bureau, illustrate the struggles rural Indians have faced in accessing financial services through the lockdown, that are only worsened by technological impediments of wrongly mapped Aadhar numbers to mobile numbers, inaccessible baking services and problems with biometric verfication.
.
Via @inetdemocracy 
.
This is a part of an ongoing series of research conducted by @so_radhikal about the lived experiences of surveillance during COVID-19 especially for marginalised communities. All illustrations by @harmeetrahal
.

caption:
ASHA workers have been at the forefront of India's healthcare system as community health workers much before the pandemic. But now, they find themselves having to take on work that they have never done before in order to tackle this crisis. Ranjit Kaur, Union Leader (Punjab), All India ASHA Worker and Facilitators Union, explains in detail the kind of problems Punjab's ASHA workers are facing while trying to do their job without proper training or technical know-how during the pandemic. Punjab government's COVID19 tracing app, 'Ghar Ghar Nigrani', has made ASHA workers agents of state surveillance--all while struggling with digital literacy, access to mobile phones and more themselves.
.
Art by @harmeetrahal
.
Please feel free to share/use the images and content, but don't forget to attribute/tag @inetdemocracy. You will have our eternal gratitude.

caption:
Posted @withregram ‚Ä¢ @inetdemocracy The COVID19 pandemic and the resulting national lockdown shifted the world in an unforeseen way. But, while most people's lives changed, not every change was the same. How did this pandemic unfold for those who continue to exist at the margins of the society? In this first vignette, @povmumbai Director Bishakha Datta highlights how technology has aided the gendered gaze of surveillance through this lockdown for various marginalised groups. 
.

caption:
Why can‚Äôt data be used for more for more futures oriented, liberatory kind of things, or even just for mental health?

It‚Äôs good to imagine the worlds you need, the futures that you want to inhabit, so that you can create it, advocate for it. And this is another reason why the design justice framework is so important. Sometimes what you are ‚Äòfor‚Äô is as important as what you are ‚Äòagainst‚Äô. 

Data Feminism is important because it helps us imagine the future we want. Read an electric exchange between @joana_varon of @codingrights and Catherine D'Ignazio (@kanarinkaprojects) of Data + Feminism at MIT on #BodiesofEvidence ‚Äî link in bio.

Image: The Oracle card of Pleasure by @cclarote. #DataFeminism #SexGenTech

caption:
‚ÄúJoy Buolamwini has the rare ability to articulate not just science, but why it matters,‚Äù says #CodedBias director @shalinikantayya

Watch her work on the film‚Äôs THEATRICAL RELEASE on NOVEMBER 11th! 
„Éª„Éª„Éª
Joy Buolamwini got Jeff Bezos to back down.
.
@joyfulcode‚Äôs research helped persuade Amazon, IBM, and Microsoft to put a hold on facial recognition technology. Through her nonprofit @ajlunited, she's now battling AI bias in other realms. Joy highlights the #FCMostCreative People of 2020.
.
Click the link in our bio to read about how Buolamwini is galvanizing a growing movement to expose the social consequences of artificial intelligence.
.

caption:
In her new article for @povmumbai, @joana_varon is in conversation with @kanarinkaprojects about data feminism and how we can use #AI to imagine & craft better futures. [LINK IN BIO]

Repost @povmumbai 
„Éª„Éª„Éª
‚ÄúOne of the weird things about data is, especially when it‚Äôs data about people, if you datafy something, you are abstracting it away from the body. It is an abstraction, almost by definition. So I like this way of putting it back into the body.‚Äù

Dive into an illuminating conversation on #datafeminism between @joana_varon (@codingrights) and @kanarinkaprojects (Data + Feminism, MIT), exclusively on #BodiesofEvidence. Link in bio.

Infographic by Diana Moreno, Natasha Feliz e Joana Varon. #SexGenTech

caption:
‚ÄúOne of the weird things about data is, especially when it‚Äôs data about people, if you datafy something, you are abstracting it away from the body. It is an abstraction, almost by definition. So I like this way of putting it back into the body.‚Äù

Dive into an illuminating conversation on #datafeminism between @joana_varon (@codingrights) and @kanarinkaprojects (Data + Feminism, MIT), exclusively on #BodiesofEvidence. Link in bio.

caption:
The problem with surveillance is that it is always pretending to ‚Äòhelp‚Äô. So while it‚Äôs ‚Äòkind of cool that Google and Apple stepped up‚Äô to do contact tracing during the pandemic, it still comes back to questions like: What is going to happen to that data on the other side of it? What happens when we give up more data points to these big corporations? And why is it always corporate platforms that we have to use? Why does this have to be a corporate thing that they get to frame as benevolence?

This electric exchange was a part of an interview between @joana_varon of @codingrights and @kanarinkaprojects (Data+Feminism, MIT) on #BodiesofEvidence. Get your weekend reading at our link in bio. #DataFeminism #SexGenTech

caption:
The tarot deck is a great place to start reimagining a transfeminist future, especially one led by technology. With this in mind, the folks at @codingrights developed the ùó¢ùóøùóÆùó∞ùóπùó≤ ùó≥ùóºùóø ùóßùóøùóÆùóªùòÄùó≥ùó≤ùó∫ùó∂ùóªùó∂ùòÄùòÅ ùóôùòÇùòÅùòÇùóøùó≤ùòÄ with multiple decks ‚Äî 'Values', 'Situations' and 'Objects'. These can be combined in various ways to explore visions of technologies that revolve around feminist principles: agency, autonomy, empathy, pleasure, and decolonisation.

Ingrained with transfeminist values, this Oracle can help us foresee a future where people who are too often excluded from (and even targeted by) technology today build the technologies for tomorrow.

Excited? Read more on #BodiesofEvidence, written by @joana_varon. Link in bio. #DataFeminism #SexGenTech

caption:
Lavorare con i dati attraverso un approccio femminista non vuol dire necessariamente occuparsi di donne o di questioni di genere: vuol dire occuparsi del potere. In particolare, di chi lo detiene e di chi no. Questa √® il messaggio chiave del libro Data Feminism di Catherine D‚ÄôIgnazio e Lauren F. Klein, da cui prende ispirazione la prima parte dell'articolo che abbiamo pubblicato sul magazine. Molto spesso si tratta di cercare DATI CHE MANCANO: dati che non ci stanno raccontando come le minoranze subiscono le conseguenze di una pandemia (e trovate il link del lavoro incredibile fatto dal blog "COVID from the margins‚Äù, oppure dati che fotografano situazioni non monitorate dalle istituzioni. Come per esempio la mappa dei medici obiettori in Italia o gli omicidi da parte della polizia negli Stati Uniti. Nel magazine trovi fonti e altri lavori a cui ispirarti, il link √® in bio. (Stai lavorando a un progetto di questo tipo? Raccontacelo!)
.
.
.
#datafeminism #dataactivism #dataninjaschool
caption_hashtags: datafeminism dataactivism dataninjaschool
all_comments_text: @sara.leano

caption:
‚ÄúIn an ideal world there wouldn‚Äôt be feminicide, let‚Äôs start from there. There wouldn‚Äôt even be a concept of such a thing as feminicide. But while there is, our aspiration is for there to be at least a minimum set of data that allows us to understand the situation of every country.‚Äù

Read ‚Äú5 Questions on Data and Feminicide with Silvana Fumega‚Äù at the #DataFeminism publication on Medium. @silvana_fumega is the research and policy director of the Latin American Open Data Initiative (@ildalatam) where she and her team have developed a much-needed standard for collecting and publishing data on femicides.
.
.
.

caption:
The technology we use has always been normative and bound in binaries and it's no surprise, because our tech also reflects the values and imaginations of those who make them. 
.
The first introduction @joana.varon (Founding Directress at @codingrights) had to technology was through video games. Yet it also frustrated her. Was there no potential for moving beyond binaries, even in an imaginary world?
.
Video games give us the chance to go into different worlds parallel universes full of potential. So then why are we still limited by the present? How can we change it?
.
Do we see possibilities in the future of daily technology to go beyond binaries and the matrix of domination? Explore this in #BodiesofEvidence. Link in bio of @povmumbai . 
.
.
@queerabad 
@queerabad 
.
.
‚ú® via the Oracle for Transfeminist Futures by @codingrights

caption:
In the last 10 years, there have been many threats to feminism on the internet. The Snowden revelations on mass surveillance was just the tip of the iceberg; beyond that we have seen sexist online attacks on feminists, women journalists, non-male gamers, female politicians or simply vocal women - all pointing towards silencing voices of dissent.

Scholar Shoshana Zuboff has explored the idea of Surveillance Capitalism: practices of gendered surveillance, including threats by partners spying on devices, online ads that reinforce gender roles, policemen infiltrating dating apps and period trackers that are often funded by the anti-abortion movement.

Is there space on the internet for decolonial, intersectional feminism? In her explosive essay, @joana_varon (Founding Directress at @codingrights) creates the landscape for a possible trans-feminist future in our technologies. Link in bio for the long read. #BodiesofEvidence #DataFeminism #SexGenTech

caption:
Technology is empowering, and it helps un-complicate our lives in many small and big ways, and also continues to entertain us and help productivity on a daily basis. But if we speculate the future of all the technologies that we interact with on a daily basis, is there room for feminism in it?

We all have lived experiences which tell us how patriarchal, heteronormative and colonial our digital technologies are. Things like having to choose a male avatar on a gaming site. Or bigger things like Snowden‚Äôs revelations on mass surveillance, coordinated online attacks on feminists, women gamers, female politicians or just vocal women, showing us that the larger agenda was to silencing voices of dissent.

To dig deeper, dive straight into @joana_varon‚Äôs essay on Deep Dives about the possibility of a trans-feminist future in our technologies ‚Äî link in our bio. She uses a virtual and physical card game, akin to a tarot deck (by @codingrights) to help us collectively imagine, reflect and share ideas for an alternative technology universe. #BodiesofEvidence #SexGenTech #DataFeminism

caption:
Work in progress - A Wandering Womb
.
This month I joined @itpcamp in an effort to dive back into my new media art practice. I closed out the month with this project that uses creative code to visualize issues in healthcare for people with uteruses.
.
In ancient greece it was thought that uteruses could wander the body & cause hysteria. While we know better today, there continues to be a massive lack of data & research about reproductive health.
.
This project specifically speaks to endometriosis. A disorder that causes endometrial tissue to grow outside of the uterus, causing uncommonly painful periods, fatigue, and more. Despite affecting 1 in 10 people with a uterus' daily lives, endometriosis takes on average 7.5 years and 7-10 doctors to diagnose.
.
This Wandering Womb, depicted as a flowering cactus, is drawn over the amount of time it typically takes to diagnose endometriosis. See code that powers the image on slide 2.
.
#endometriosis #datafeminism #wip #newmedia #p5js

caption:
‚ÄúInequality can be measured. Inequality isn't that I'm angry or complaining. Inequality isn't a feeling of mine. Inequality is something that exists, that we can see, that we can measure...
.
.
Data helps us build arguments to debate this with more authority and reliability. They are also useful for us because if we want to transform our society, we have to diagnose the problems. The average unemployment rate in Argentina is 10%, and the unemployment rate for young women under the age of 29 is 20%. Why does this happen with women under the age of 29? Maybe it‚Äôs because they're at a childbearing age, and that makes them withdraw from the labor market; or maybe people don't want to hire them because they'll be absent. And that's important, because it allows us to think how we can improve the access conditions to the labor market for these women, or if there's sufficient provision of childcare.‚Äù Read the full interview with Mercedes D‚ÄôAlessandro, @metxi0, co-creator of Econom√≠a Feminista, at the #DataFeminism publication on Medium today! And don‚Äôt forget to purchase the book from @mitpress
.
.

https://medium.com/data-feminism

Glad to say I‚Äôve updated my data science framework to be revisited with critical feminist and ethnic studies theory, and gave me food for my starved engineering soul.

caption: I‚Äôm only at intro and this book is already blowing my mind. It‚Äôs not simply about disparities between the sexes, but largely about disparities based on race. Data science by whom? Data science for whom? With whose interest in mind? So incredibly relevant. ‚ÄúData feminism reminds us that before there are data, there are people- people who offer up their experience to be counted and analyzed, people who visualize the data and promote the findings of any particular project and people who use the product at the end‚Äù. While you are at it, check out Data for Black Lives, www.d4bl.org. #dataforblacklives #datafeminism #blm #learning #booksthatmatter
caption_hashtags: dataforblacklives datafeminism blm learning booksthatmatter

caption:
Reading about feminism always takes me out of my comfort zone as it makes me hyper conscious of all the privileges I have had as a male for decades. And it questions whether I would be where I am without all those privileges.

Simple things like being able to run outside whenever I want to, taking any route while walking, falling asleep on a train ride are all things I never had to think of as scary until I engage with feminism.

This book deepened my understanding of how entrenched the system is biased against women and has been for millennia. It really hit me to realise that the world as we know it now is designed for men and designed by men. This leads to tragic instances which this book goes into the details. .
.
.

#books #feminism #feministbooks #datafeminism #mumbaibookstagrammer #booksofinstagram #booksbooksbooks #booksofig #injustice #whenwillthisend
caption_hashtags: books feminism feministbooks datafeminism mumbaibookstagrammer booksofinstagram booksbooksbooks booksofig injustice whenwillthisend
all_comments_text: This was a great read. A world that is designed to serve the able, heterosexual man. @@@ I loved this book so much. I thought I knew how bad patriarchy is for anyone else except men, turns out I did not know the half of it! An absolute must-read!!

Shalini Kantayya (Director/Producer)
codedbias.com
CODED BIAS explores the fallout of mit media lab researcher Joy Buolamwini‚Äôs startling discovery that facial recognition does not see dark-skinned faces accurately, and her journey to push for the first-ever legislation in the U.S. to govern against bias in the algorithms that impact us all.

caption:
What are you currently reading?
.
üêò Hi, Bookstagram, I've missed you! Taking a step back from social media was great, but I'm happy to be back. I missed the community, and I've missed chatting with the wonderful friends I've made on here. Still, it was great to take time to reflect on how I want to continue educating myself and to chat with people about current issues.
.
So our post today is from @glassbookshop our amazing local bookstore. .
üìä Data Feminism is by Catherine D'Ignazio and Lauren F. Klein, and it presents a new way of thinking about data science and data ethics that heavily based upon intersectional feminism. A lot of my library friends have been reading this book and they've been talking about how amazing it is. .
üî• Dear Sir l, I Intend to Burn Your Book: An Anatomy of a Book Burning by Lawrence Hill (author of The Book of Negroes) - this was recommended by a friend of mine, and I'm excited to read it because censorship is something I'm passionate about, and because I get to support a black Canadian author as well.
.
Of course we're reading lots of fantasy and YA as well ‚ù§Ô∏è Can't wait to share the amazing books we've recently read!
.

caption:
üá¶üá∑ #FemiData
‚†Ä
"Desde el 20 de marzo al 28 de mayo se registraron al menos 57 femicidios, seg√∫n el Observatorio de @lacasadelencuentro. El 70% fueron mujeres asesinadas en sus viviendas en manos de sus parejas.
‚†Ä
Desde hace m√°s de diez a√±os la estad√≠stica de un femicidio cada 30 horas no s√≥lo no baja; en per√≠odos de mayor desigualdad como el que vivimos, se incrementa.
‚†Ä
El grito por #NiUnaMenos sigue tan vigente como en 2015.
‚†Ä
Por esto planteamos la necesidad de declarar la Emergencia Nacional en violencia contra las mujeres.
‚†Ä
Hoy est√° presentado en el Congreso de la Naci√≥n un proyecto a discutir sobre esta emergencia en tiempos de pandemia, que incluye un presupuesto con partidas presupuestarias extraordinarias para:
‚†Ä
- asistencia y prevenci√≥n
‚†Ä
- centros de d√≠a y refugios
‚†Ä
- patrocinio jur√≠dico
‚†Ä
- asignaci√≥n econ√≥mica mensual
‚†Ä
- plan de promotoras comunitarias en prevenci√≥n y acompa√±amiento".
‚†Ä
Fuente: @_niunamenos_ Comodoro Rivadavia
‚†Ä
‚†Ä
üíú üôã‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è üíú üôã‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è üíú üôã‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è üíú üôã‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è üíú üôã‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è üíú üôã‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è üíú üôã‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è üíú üôã‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è üíú
‚†Ä
‚†Ä
üá¨üáß #datafeminism
‚†Ä
From March 20 to May 28, at least 57 femicides were registered, according to the Observatory of the NGO @lacasadelencuentro. 70 % were women murdered in their homes by their partners.
‚†Ä
For more than 10 years the statistic of a femicide every 30 hours has not decreased, and in some periods of greater inequality such as the one we are experiencing, it has increased.
‚†Ä
The #NotOneLess is still as valid as in 2015.
‚†Ä
This is why we raised many years ago the need for a National Emergency declaration on violence against women.
‚†Ä
Today a bill to discuss this emergency in times of pandemic is in the National Congress, and it includes an extraordinary budget for:
‚†Ä
- care and prevention
‚†Ä
- day centers and shelters
‚†Ä
- legal sponsorship
‚†Ä
- monthly financial allowance
‚†Ä
- plan for community promoters in prevention and accompaniment
‚†Ä
‚†Ä
‚†Ä

caption:
"Who made this? Who collected the data? Whose lives are embodied in the data? Who is it serving? Who is harmed potentially?" Last month I joined Catherine D'Ignazio and Lauren F. Klein's excellent reading group Data Feminism, and it's been one of the best things ever.

I can't recommend this book enough!

#datafeminism #data #ethics #technology
caption_hashtags: datafeminism data ethics technology

caption:
‚ÄúData Feminism‚Äù Catherine D‚ÄôIgnazio. Los cambios son necesarios, por lo menos asiÃÅ lo ve la escritora de este libro. Libros como este, nos recuerdan como humanidad y nos hacen ver que las acciones del hoy pueden tener una cantidad de ecos maÃÅs grande, de lo que se podriÃÅa antes. El feminismo no es solo un salir a las calles a marchar, sino representa una oportunidad para que todos, juntos podamos crear un cambio y aplicarlo en lo conocemos bien.

SeleccioneÃÅ este chaleco, que se ocupa en los modelos de CPR, porque gracias a que se escuchara la voz de las mujeres, maÃÅs de ellas pudieron encontrar fallas o machismos escondidos en sus propias disciplinas. En este caso la industria meÃÅdica representa una de los ejemplos maÃÅs grandes y sorprendentes, ya que la salud debe ser resguardada por todos y para todas, y si estas sesgada la informacioÃÅn por solo tomar en cuenta a los hombres, estamos perdidos y ellas desprotegidas. ‚ÄúUna mujer no es un hombre chiquito‚Äù

caption:
Join us for Data Feminism-- A Crowdcast Luncheon with Catherine D'Ignazio (@kanarinkaprojects) and Lauren F. Klein (@proleptic) This event is co-sponsored by The Lola a Womxn's Club and Community (@thelola_women). The Lola's mission is to bring together womxn as allies and accomplices to tell our stories, raise our voices and dismantle a system that doesn't serve us. 
_______________________________
In Data Feminism, Catherine D'Ignazio and Lauren Klein present a new way of thinking about data science and data ethics--one that is informed by intersectional feminist thought.

Data Feminism offers strategies for data scientists seeking to learn how feminism can help them work toward justice, and for feminists who want to focus their efforts on the growing field of data science. But Data Feminism is about much more than gender. It is about power, about who has it and who doesn't, and about how those differentials of power can be challenged and changed.
_______________________________

Crowdcast: Link in Bio
Publisher: @mitpress

Could you tell she is a rockstar cyber security expert? 
Adriana recently explained to me the five steps of incidence management in computer viruses - planning & preparation, detection & triage, containment & analysis, post incidence assessment and closure. It does relate to some degree with how we are handling an epidemic, doesn‚Äôt it? ü§î
Only 11% of the cyber security positions worldwide are occupied by women, in Europe that number is 7%. That means that the cyber security industry is missing out on almost half of the population‚Äôs talent pool, during a period in history when cyber crimes have become ubiquitous and the market has grown more than 30x in 13 years. Maybe an opportunity?

caption:
Although we are disappointed to not be hosting Data Feminism co-authors Catherine D‚ÄôIgnazio (@kanarinkaprojects) and Lauren Klein (@proleptic) tonight as we had initially scheduled,  we are excited to celebrate their book, and hope to reschedule their event soon. As Data Feminism posits, data science is a form of power, never more so than now, in the time of coronavirus, when we are all trying to make sense of new data all the time. Data has been used to expose injustice, improve health outcomes, and topple governments. But it has also been used to discriminate, police, and surveil. This potential for good, on the one hand, and harm, on the other, makes it essential to ask: Data science by whom? Data science for whom? Data science with whose interests in mind? The narratives around big data and data science are overwhelmingly white, male, and techno-heroic. In Data Feminism, Catherine D'Ignazio and Lauren Klein present a new way of thinking about data science and data ethics--one that is informed by intersectional feminist thought. Data Feminism offers strategies for data scientists seeking to learn how feminism can help them work toward justice, and for feminists who want to focus their efforts on the growing field of data science. But Data Feminism is about much more than gender. It is about power, about who has it and who doesn't, and about how those differentials of power can be challenged and changed. 
Order Data Feminism online from Charis Books and More today via the link in our bio.

Many women under lockdown for ‚Ä™#COVID19‚Ä¨ face violence where they should be safest: in their own homes. Even before COVID19 existed, domestic violence was already one of the greatest human rights violations. In the previous 12 months, according to UN Women, 243 million women and girls (aged 15-49) across the world have been subjected to sexual or physical violence by an intimate partner. As the COV19 pandemic continues, this number is likely to grow with multiple impacts on women‚Äôs wellbeing, their sexual and reproductive health, their mental health, and their ability to participate and lead in the recovery of our societies and economy. .

caption:
As we move toward an increasingly data-driven world, it is essential to ask: Data science by whom? Data science for whom? Data science with whose interests in mind? 
Catherine D'Ignazio, assistant professor of urban science and planning at MIT, believes the answer lies in intersectional feminism, a concept explored in her new book, Data Feminism.

Coauthored by Laura Klein, the book calls for an infusion of an intersectional feminist ethos to data processing. This framework is needed to ensure data science is a tool of justice rather than a high-tech form of oppression.

#DataFeminism #IWLBooksWeRecommend

caption: ‚ÄúWe began by just mapping evictions in San Francisco that had taken place beginning in the first Dot Com Boom and extending into the present. But we have since wanted to create maps that could show deeper histories of racialized dispossession, colonialism and events that have kind of laid the bedrock for the contemporary displacement crisis to be what it is.‚Äù Read our full interview with Erin McElroy, co-founder of @antievictionmap, about using data to fight for housing justice at #DataFeminism on Medium and pre-order today from @mitpress! https://medium.com/data-feminism

caption:
"Data Feminism is a powerful call to action for everyone who cares about how technology reflects and reproduces social hierarchies and injustices. Brilliantly argued, engagingly written, and collaboratively crafted, this groundbreaking work enacts a feminist politics of knowledge production that will serve as a guide for generations to come." -- Ruha Benjamin (@ruha9), Princeton University, author of Race after Technology

caption:
Repost from @mitpress

The MIT Libraries are proud to support the Strong Ideas series, a hybrid print and open access book series for general readers that provides fresh, strongly argued, and provocative views of the effects of digital technology on culture, business, government, education, and our lives.

Data Feminism = A new way of thinking about data science and data ethics that is informed by the ideas of intersectional feminism. Catherine D'Ignazio and Lauren F. Klein show how challenges to the male/female binary can help challenge other hierarchical classification systems: An understanding of emotion can expand our ideas about effective data visualization. The concept of invisible labor can expose the significant human efforts required by our automated systems. D‚ÄôIgnazio and Klein also make sure to show why the data never, ever ‚Äúspeak for themselves.‚Äù This book is for data scientists who want to work toward justice and feminists who want to expand their efforts. But this book is also about power: who has it and who doesn't, and about how those differentials of power can be challenged and changed.

#DataFeminism #intersectional #feminism #OpenAccess #StrongIdeas #PubPub #LaurenKlein #CatherineDignazio #gender #power #DataScience #justice #feminist #MITPress

‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢
Intentional Futures

For Speculative Futures Seattle‚Äôs first event, three members of the UW community ‚Äì Audrey Desjardins, Regina Yung Lee, and Afroditi Psarra ‚Äì shared their work and discussed how they think about and design more preferable futures. 
Some themes that emerged across their talks were the inherent bias in data, what we can learn about ourselves from the process of encoding and decoding data, and the power of narrative as a way for humans to makes sense of technology and the world around us.

Visit the link in our bio for a recap, links to resources mentioned by our panelists, and a transcript of the talk. Thank you so much to everyone who made it out and stay tuned for more media from this event and an announcement about our next event!

caption:
‚ÄúPeople are using the data to mystify the solutions when we know what the solutions are. This is where data has served a purpose, but there‚Äôs an important tipping point that we have passed, and now it is just contributing to a deficit narrative where Black women need to be saved. 
White people are like, ‚ÄúHow can we save Black women?‚Äù And that‚Äôs not the solution that we need the data to produce.‚Äù Read the full interview with Kimberly Seals Allers - @iamksealsallers - in which she talks about deficit narratives, health disparities, and her new app @TheIrthApp - on Medium and pre-order #DataFeminism from @mitpress. https://medium.com/data-feminism

caption:
‚ÄúLife in Kibera taught me how to be resilient, to rise up and not give up to fear.‚Äù When she was 16, Paulin was gang raped in her neighbourhood and received death threats to stay silent. She married at 19 to an abusive husband and by 21, she had had two kids. She stayed home and silently took care of them. Paulin‚Äôs mom encouraged her to raise her voice and stand for herself and other women. Paulin found courage when she was 22. She shared her story widely and since then she has created a safe space for women and men who have experienced domestic violence and sexual assault under the initiative ‚ÄúRebirth of a Queen.‚Äù She has so far supported 60 women and 10 men who have been sexually abused in Kibera. Paulin has dedicated her life to protecting others by breaking the silence and taboos associated with sexual abuse and domestic violence. 
Approximately 15 million adolescent girls (aged 15 to 19) worldwide have experienced forced sex at some point in their life. In the vast majority of countries, adolescent girls are most at risk of forced sex by a current/former husband, partner or boyfriend. Based on data from 30 countries, only one per cent ever sought professional help.
.
.
.
.
.
.
#domesticviolence #sexualabuse #silence #kibera #nairobi #kenya #womenempowerment #gebderdatagap #datafeminism #nowomanislimited

caption: üó£In our brand new Medium publication, we showcase interviews conducted for the book #DataFeminism (pre-order now from @mitpress) with luminaries like @DrDesmondPatton, @JuliaAngwin, and @mathbabedotorg. New content coming every Friday, so watch this space‚ùóÔ∏è https://medium.com/data-feminism/about ////// Data Feminism is a new way of thinking about data science and data ethics that is informed by the ideas of intersectional feminism. Today, data science is a form of power. It has been used to expose injustice, improve health outcomes, and topple governments. But it has also been used to discriminate, police, and surveil. This potential for good, on the one hand, and harm, on the other, makes it essential to ask: Data science by whom? Data science for whom? Data science with whose interests in mind?
caption_hashtags: datafeminism

caption:
It‚Äôs the world day of #SocialJustice and I want to introduce you to Julie, a student, a human rights activist, a mom, a creator, a superwoman from Mathare, Kenya.
I met Julie in her house on a beautiful Sunday afternoon. As I walked in, her husband was cooking and cleaning in the kitchen, and taking care of their one year old twin daughters. At that time, I already knew things are different in her family. Julie was born and raised in Mathare, a collection of slums near Nairobi, notorious for police brutality and abuse of power. Four years ago, there was at least one killing by a police a week. No one was hold accountable. Police killings were normalised in her community. The victims were just numbers. One of them was her brother. Julie started the first Social Justice Center in an informal community in Kenya. She documented and shared the stories of the killed men. By making the victims visible, police started taking note. Judiciary execution has decreased by over 50% in the past few years. The Mathare Social Justice Center has inspired other informal communities to start their own and today there are in total 24 social justice centres in all Kenya. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt stand injustice so I decided to stand up to it.‚Äù As a vivid reader, Julie also runs a book club for kids in Mathare. She uses the space to read together with kids and teach them the importance of civic engagement and activism. And at night, she goes to school.
She reminds us all to stand up, speak up and don‚Äôt give up until human rights are protected.
.
.
.
#socialjusticeday #humanrights #justice #women #kenya #mathare #superwoman #womenempowerment #datafeminism #genderdatagap #feminism #nowomanislimited

caption:
A warning to all women! "While I am incredibly grateful for the scientific advances in medicine, life-saving antibiotics and vaccines that improve our health and vitality every day, the continued trope that women need more science, data or things to guide basic parenting decisions, especially in the early days of motherhood, is a dangerous undermining of women that should concern us all. 
It is no coincidence that much of the scientific focus that diminishes and attacks maternal intuition and cultural norms is related to birth and breastfeeding ‚Äî things that women‚Äôs bodies uniquely do." This trend should concern us all! Thank you @theriveterco for sharing my thoughts today. Full story in Linküå≥

Data and science have great potential to support and improve the mothering experience, instead it has mostly silenced and suppressed women. "After years of feminist fighting to free ourselves from the control of men dictating our lives and undermining women‚Äôs decisions, many are simply handing over their autonomy as mothers to a new overseer: a scientific report." How can data be a tool for change for women & mothers? 
#motherhood #mothering #feminism #writing #data #datascience #maternalhealth #writingmotherhood #rewritingmotherhood #datafeminism
caption_hashtags: motherhood mothering feminism writing data datascience maternalhealth writingmotherhood rewritingmotherhood datafeminism

caption:
Cata is a feminist, a gender expert and an LGBT activist who grew up in Bogot√°, Colombia. She has the superpower to make people see the world with a gender lens through stories and facts. And once you see, you cannot unsee the world designed by men for men. 
My conversations with Cata inspired the idea of @no.woman.is.limited , which aims to inspire many more to see the world through the eyes of women. 
Still today, male norm continues to go unquestioned. The male norm is universal, in medical trials, in the workplace, in the public life, everywhere. It is about time that we start designing women in. 
And once you see, act and pass the gender glasses forward!
.
.
.
.

caption:
To honour the International Day for Women and Girls in Science, let me introduce you to Nancy, a data scientist from Kenya who works in Uganda. Nancy holds a Masters Degree in Information Technology from Carnegie Mellon University in Rwanda. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve always been the monitory, in classes, in meetings.. in 80% of the classes I attended I was the only woman. I felt like I needed to claim the space for women in science. It empowered me and today I want to encourage other women to get into the field and not be afraid to speak up, even if they are the only woman in the room.‚Äù Only 26% of AI and data professionals globally are women. The world needs science, and science needs women. üíÉüèæ
.
.

.

caption:
Did you know? ü§î 
As late as 1970, the top five orchestras in the U.S. had fewer than 5% women. It wasn't until 1980 that any of these top orchestras had 10% female musicians. But by 1997 they were up to 25% and today some of them are well into the 30%. In the 1970s and 1980s, orchestras began using blind auditions. Researchers have determined that this step alone makes it 50% more likely that a woman will advance to the finals. During the final round, ‚Äúblind‚Äù auditions increased the likelihood of female musicians being selected by 30%. .
.
.
